Deshmukh Marg, Mumbai - 400 026, Maharashtra, Mellitus](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-mellitus-3807.html) (T2 DM) is an ancient disease, discussed 3500 years ago in literature. Vast population worldwide is suffering from this disease and yet it is found to be untreatable. As per WHO statistics 2012, the number of deaths in the world due to T2 DM almost reached to 1.5 million. The number of people suffering from T2 DM in India is expected to rise from 40.9 million in 2007 to 69.9 million in 2025 due to change in their life style. Of the two types of DM- Type 1 and Type 2, the latter is most common, affecting 80% of DM patients. Modern lifestyle and food habits have been responsible for tremendous rise in the number of patients all over the world. Even though, the symptoms of T2 DM are seen in the later stages of life, the onset of the disease occurs quite early. Insulin resistance and cell dysfunction are the main causative abnormalities. Several [mutations](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/mutations-9811.html) in the genes important for glucose [homeostasis](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/homeostasis-8187.html) and cell development have been related to progress of hyperglycemia, while this progress is related to various metabolic syndromes arising in the patients' body. Thus, forming a vicious circle of the causes and effects of hyperglycemia interlinked together forming the whole picture of T2 DM in the patient. This review discusses these causes and effects at the molecular and cellular levels. The current therapy practices use of oral therapeutic drugs, which controls hyperglycemia and related complications but fails to cure the disease permanently. Hence, [stem cell therapy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cell-therapy-6987.html) has drawn interest of the researchers in recent times, which seems to be a promising source of remedy for this notorious disease. This review will provide a better understanding of T2 DM and associated complications, recent advances in the therapy and the molecular and cellular insights of the disease to the students, clinicians, endocrinologists and diabetologists. Keywords Diabetes mellitus, [stem cell](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cell-770.html) therapy, molecular markers, metabolic syndrome, [gene](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/gene-4901.html) regulation Introduction Diabetes Mellitus (DM) is a disease known to humankind since a very long time. The disease has been mentioned in 3500 years old literature. The etymology of the name [diabetes mellitus](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-mellitus-3807.html) states its meaning as "the sweet flow or siphon." In spite of being such an ancient disease a complete cure for DM is not available till date [ [1](#1)]. Millions of people all over the world are suffering from this disease; the incidence of DM is increasing year by year due to several reasons [ [1](#1)]. In India, 40.9 million people were suffering from DM in 2007. The number is expected to rise up to 69.9 million by 2025 [ [2](#2)]. The common symptoms of this disease are hyperglycemia, frequent urination, polyuria, polydipsia, and unexplained weight loss. Diabetic patients often show abnormalities termed altogether as "metabolic syndrome." The indicative signs of this syndrome are high blood levels of triglycerides and low blood levels of high density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol which increase the risk of developing heart diseases in human [ [1](#1), [3](#3)]. [Diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) often leads to several complications such as stroke, myocardial infarction, loss of vision, renal failure and neuropathies. There are major two types of DM, Type 1 and Type 2. Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) is an autoimmune disease caused due to disturbance in T-cell mediated [immune response](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/immune-response-2227.html) of [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) of pancreas; whereas (T2DM) is caused due to [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) due to failure of cell function. However, exact mechanism of insulin resistance is not yet known and further study in this area is needed. DM patients show impaired glucose tolerance, which is mainly caused by impaired insulin action and insulin secretory malfunction [ [4](#4)- [6](#6)]. The predisposing factors are genetic susceptibility, [environmental](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/environmental-12701.html) factors and lifestyle. The facets of modern lifestyle such as physical inactivity, sedentary habits, overly rich nutrition, cigarette smoking, consumption of alcohol and [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) have led to increase in spread of [diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) [ [7](#7)- [9](#9)]. This review will overview major [information](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/information-7757.html) about causation of T2DM at cellular and molecular level. It also highlights possible cure by advanced drug discovery program and [stem cell](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cell-770.html) therapy. This review will be very much useful for Post-graduate students working on DM as well as for clinicians to get a proper picture of T2DM so that they can plan precise treatment protocol for successful cure of this disease. Mechanism involved in the onset and progress of T2DM In humans, after glucose intake, normal glucose [homeostasis](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/homeostasis-8187.html) mainly occurs through three major pathways. First, insulin is secreted by pancreas; second, decline in glucose production by liver cells; third, stimulation of glucose uptake by liver and peripheral muscles [ [10](#10), [11](#11)]. Shulman et al. [ [12](#12)] has further shown that muscle glycogen synthesis is the principal pathway of glucose disposal in both normal and diabetic subjects and thus defects in muscle glycogen synthesis plays very important role in the insulin resistance in T2DM. It has also been proved by Warrem et al. [ [13](#13)] that the symptoms of DM can be noticed one to two decades before the actual occurrence of this disease in offspring of diabetic patients. They have also shown that these patients have hyperglycemic state, which is recompensed by hyperinsulinemia. No hypoinsulinemia is observed at this stage thereby indicating that much before the loss of cell activity the defect arises in peripheral tissue response to glucose. Hence, it can be stated that insulin resistance and not insulin deficiency leads to the onset of T2DM in these patients. T2DM patients show low concentrations of Glucose-6-phosphate and reduced rate of non-oxidative glucose metabolism. This indicates that either hexokinase or insulin stimulated glucose transport activity is reduced in patients. Rothman et al. [ [14](#14)] has shown that the reduction in insulin stimulated muscle glycogen synthesis may increase the risk of [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) in patients with T2DM. This reduction in the rate of muscle glycogen synthesis indicates faulty glucose transport or hexokinase activity. They have further concluded that the offspring of parents with T2DM have defect in muscle glucose transport/hexokinase activity causing [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) much before the onset of hyperglycemia and this may be primary factor in the [pathogenesis](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/pathogenesis-19450.html) of T2DM. Cline et al. [ [15](#15)] has also indicated that the defect in glucose transport/phosphorylation is the major factor responsible for reducing the rate of muscle glycogen synthesis in T2DM patients. The hyperglycemic state results in inflammation and stimulates [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) to produce Interleukin-1 (IL-1) at higher rate. The lower concentration of IL-1 antagonist fails to compete and bind the receptors. This results in cell destruction and loss of function. Goyal et al. [ [16](#16)] has studied TNF- and Interleukin-6 (IL-6) levels in obese and non-obese diabetic patients before and after insulin therapy and they found that there is increased [inflammation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/inflammation-2448.html) in obese diabetic patients than in non-obese diabetic patients. They have further stated that to counteract this [inflammation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/inflammation-2448.html) in obese patients, the response to insulin treatment is delayed than in non-obese [diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) patients. Since completion of human [genome](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/genome-18800.html) project, several scientists are focused on finding out molecular mechanism of T2DM. Recently Saini et al. [ [17](#17)] has overviewed several such mechanisms involved in T2DM. Marino et al. [ [18](#18)] has studied major mechanisms involved in defective insulin stimulated glucose transport activity in DM patients. They have shown that there is an increase in intramyocellular lipid metabolites such as fatty acyl CoAs and diacylglycerol in DM patients. These molecules activate serine/threonine kinase cascade and lead to phosphorylation of insulin receptor substrate (IRS)-1 thus leading to defects in insulin signaling in these patients. They have further correlated reduction in mitochondrial function in the insulin resistant offspring of DM patients and thus by understanding these cellular and molecular mechanisms for insulin resistance there is a possibility of providing potential new targets for therapies of T2DM. Akt plays a very important role in the insulinsignaling pathway via activation of insulin dependent glucose transporter protein GLUT4. Martin et al. [ [19](#19)] has shown that GLUT4 undergoes insulin dependent movement to the cell surface in adipocytes. These data suggest that, GLUT4 is selectively organized into a vesicular compartment in adipocytes and then transferred to the plasma membrane on insulin stimulation. Recent animal experimentations have shown that PKB (Akt2) isoform knockout mice exhibit [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) and its [phenotype](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/phenotype-17138.html) closely resembles T2DM in humans. This explains that Akt2 is an essential factor in the maintenance of normal glucose [homeostasis](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/homeostasis-8187.html) in humans [ [20](#20), [21](#21)]. George et al. [ [22](#22)] has suggested that inherited defects in signaling pathways may contribute to [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) in human T2DM. The studies revealed that autosomal dominant inheritance of severe [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) and DM in a family was related to [mutations](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/mutations-9811.html) in kinase AKT2/PKB domain. The insulin receptor substrate (IRS)- 1 is a major component of the insulin signal transduction pathway and mainly mediates both the metabolic and mitogenic responses to insulin [ [23](#23)]. Several investigators have examined the IRS-1 [gene](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/gene-4901.html) in insulin resistant T2DM patients and shown that more than 11 amino acids polymorphisms have been identified and [mutations](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/mutations-9811.html) in the IRS-1 protein are associated with [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) in human muscle and fat [ [24](#24), [25](#25)]. Kido et al. [ [26](#26)] has demonstrated in mice that IRS-1 and IRS-2 play important roles in the regulation and function of individual [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) and [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) developed in these mice due to cell failure. Studies have shown that serine phosphorylation of IRS proteins reduces the ability of IRS proteins to attract PI3- kinase resulting in reduction in activation and subsequent degradation of the IRS-1 protein [ [27](#27)- [29](#29)]. Insulin resistance and pancreatic cell dysfunction are major factors for cause of T2DM. It is also shown that there is reduction in cell mass in severe DM. Nakae et al. [ [30](#30)] has shown that Foxo 1 [gene](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/gene-4901.html) is a negative regulator of insulin sensitivity in liver, adipocytes and pancreatic cells. Recently Kitamura [ [31](#31)] has reviewed the role of Foxo1 in cell dysfunction and DM. Potdar et al. [ [32](#32)] has shown that [mesenchymal stem cell](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/mesenchymal-stem-cell-17160.html) derived from peripheral blood of insulin resistant DM patient showed down regulation of Sox2 gene. This indicates that there is loss of pluripotency in these MSCs as well as they have further postulated that it may link to alteration of self-renewal properties of cells. Chronic hyperglycemia is a major cause of diabetic [cardiovascular](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cardiovascular-14501.html) and microvascular complications, such as retinopathy, neuropathy and [nephropathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/nephropathy-17261.html) [ [33](#33)]. It is further shown that increase in formation of diacylglycerol (DAG) and activation of protein kinase C (PKC) formed advanced glycated end products which are responsible for development of vascular complications in patients. Das Evcimen et al. [ [33](#33)] has shown that the activation of the DAGPKC pathway is associated with many vascular abnormalities in the retinal, renal, neural and [cardiovascular](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cardiovascular-14501.html) [tissues](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/tissues-15167.html) in T2DM. PKC isoforms, nPKCs plays major role in insulin signaling. Several studies have demonstrated a link between nPKCs and FFAs induced [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) in DM patients [ [34](#34), [35](#35)]. Noh et al. [ [36](#36)] have reviewed the pathogenic role for the activation of DAG-PKC pathway in diabetic nephropathy and other microvascular complications in T2DM. Numerous mechanisms have been proposed to explain the association between hyperglycemia and vascular complications [ [37](#37), [38](#38)]. It is proposed to aim for an inhibitor of PKC isoform as a new therapeutics molecule, over viewing the involvement of PKC in diabetic vascular diseases, to delay or stop the progression of diabetic vascular complications in T2DM with minimal side effects. Lifestyle, [Obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) and T2DM Many life style habits are responsible for prevalence of T2DM such as overweight, obesity, lack of physical activity, family history, Vitamin A deficiency, use of cholesterol lowering drugs, etc. [ [39](#39)]. We know [diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) and obesity interrelation from the earliest descriptions of the disease. The modern lifestyle and foodstuffs have resulted in an increase in [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) and thus [diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) cases. Most of the patients who are above 50 years age and overweight are suffering from T2DM [ [7](#7)]. [Obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) is an important factor linked to DM however, exact relation and mechanism is inadequately understood. Ozcan et al. [ [40](#40)] has worked to show that [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) leads to endoplasmic reticulum stress, which plays an important role in peripheral [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) and hence in occurrence of T2DM at the molecular, cellular, and organismal levels. Fiber and fat content of the diet, alcohol consumption, smoking habit and sedentary lifestyle play a significant role in prevalence of DM. A higher incidence of DM is linked to Body Mass Index higher (BMI) than 25 kg/m2. The results are similar worldwide as reported in studies from all over. The association between BMI and DM occurrence is found to be stronger among younger, than among older individuals [ [41](#41)- [43](#43)]. A research on Pima Indians reveals that incidence of DM and [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) has increased in this century. This is possibly due to the changes in lifestyle and diet of the people who are already genetically susceptible to diabetes. The risk is higher when one of the parents is diabetic and even higher when both the parents are diabetic [ [8](#8)]. The current therapies like insulin, diet, exercise, behavior modification, and oral agents, fail to return patients to long-term euglycemia. Gastric bypass seems to be a promising option to restore and maintain normal levels of glucose, insulin, and HbA1c. It also reduces considerable amount of body fat. The possible reasons for the success of gastric bypass could be- total caloric intake is limited, proportion of carbohydrates in the diet is reduced, food is excluded from the hormonally active parts of the digestive system i.e. antrum, duodenum, and proximal jejunum, transit time from the stomach to the small intestine is delayed due to the small gastric outlet. This operative procedure can also prove to reverse other related complications like cardiopulmonary function, cure sleep apnea and snoring, control asthma, clear peptic reflux, improve physical activity of patients suffering from arthritis, and restore [fertility](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/fertility-2627.html) [ [44](#44)]. Lifestyle changes along with proper medications can prove to control morbidity and mortality of [diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) and related metabolic syndromes. Recent study by Imamura et al. [ [39](#39)] has shown that regular consumption of sugar-sweetened drinks, fruit juice or artificially sweetened drinks may have the risk of T2DM. They have further suggested that sugary drinks are associated with greater risk of obesity, which is a major risk factor for T2DM. In general, fruit juice and artificially sweetened beverages are recommended for good health. However, it is not clear whether, consuming such drinks can be blameless for occurrence of T2DM because these factors are responsible for development of [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) and eventually responsible for developing DM. Li et al. [ [45](#45)] have found that birth weight along with lifestyle in adulthood is related to T2DM. They have suggested that prenatal and postnatal factors are both responsible for causing DM. In addition, it has been shown that unhealthy lifestyles such as smoking, irregular and unhealthy diet, less physical activity, alcohol consumption and high BMI are responsible for causation of [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) and DM in human. The study concluded that T2DM could be prevented by adoption of healthier lifestyle and improvement in prenatal and postnatal factors. Role of NF-B and NF-B Regulated Cytokines in T2DM NF-B is a transcription factor, which plays an important role in many biological processes. It regulates the expression of various cytokines, growth factors and other molecules. There are five different of arrested in inactive state by Inhibitor of NF-B (IB) in cytoplasm in normal condition. to nucleus. Protein IB kinase (IKK) phosphorylates IB, thereby leading to the degradation process of IB protein and hence NF-B is activated. This occurs in several disease conditions [ [46](#46)]. Recent studies have shown that NF-B and NF- B regulated cytokines play significant role in development of T2DM [ [47](#47), [48](#48)]. NF-B levels are elevated in obese and diabetic patients. The accumulation of FFAs in liver causes [inflammation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/inflammation-2448.html) by NF-B pathway and release of cytokines, which eventually leads to [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) [ [49](#49), [50](#50)]. Arkan et al. [ [51](#51)] has demonstrated the importance of IKK in [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) and also the role of NF-B as the main causal factor in prevalence of DM. The higher concentration of IKK leads to over activation of NF-B. This could be reversed by salicylate inhibition of IKK [ [50](#50)]. Obesity brings about alteration in expressions of genes of [hormones](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/hormones-6945.html) and cytokines in adipocytes. TNF is an adiponectin which plays a crucial role in [lipid metabolism](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/lipid-metabolism-13990.html) and insulin resistance [ [52](#52), [53](#53)]. TNF is also associated with BMI, body fat distribution and cell dysfunction due to [autoimmunity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/autoimmunity-6075.html) and cytokine production [ [54](#54), [55](#55)]. This results in elevation of FFAs concentration by stimulation of lipolysis, and negative regulation of important insulin sensitizing nuclear receptor, Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG). Thus, neutralization of TNF could possibly be helpful in reversing the effects of insulin resistance and preventing cell [apoptosis](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/apoptosis-5333.html) [ [56](#56), [57](#57)]. High plasma levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) and IL-6 also contribute to [inflammation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/inflammation-2448.html) and insulin resistance. Insulin resistance caused due to IL-6 was shown to be reversed by systemic neutralization of IL-6 in mice [ [50](#50), [53](#53), [58](#58)]. IL-1 receptor antagonist is reduced in T2DM and therefore increases in IL-1 concentration, resulted due to high glucose level, brings about cell dysfunction and hence affects insulin regulation. Larsen et al. [ [59](#59)] has stated that blocking IL-1 with anakinara helps to control hyperglycemia, improve cell functions and insulin sensitivity and overcome inflammation. Liu et al. [ [60](#60)] has mentioned about the upregulation of IL-1 in patients with diabetic retinopathy. The role of NF-B and NF-B regulated cytokines have also been mentioned in prevalence of diabetic [nephropathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/nephropathy-17261.html) [ [61](#61), [62](#62)], [64](#64)]. Chronic activation of inflammatory pathways in skeletal muscle is one of the major factors in the [pathology](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/pathology-11993.html) of obesity, [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) and T2DM [ [65](#65)]. More than 75-80% of glucose disposal in humans is through skeletal muscle and therefore impairment of insulin action in this tissue is major site for insulin resistance. Of late, Green et al. [ [66](#66)] has shown that NF-B signaling serves as an indicator of inflammatory signaling pathway in skeletal muscle. Overall, it suggests that control of NF-B and NF-B regulated cytokines may prove to be a useful treatment for T2DM. Role of Mitochondrial DNA in T2DM Insulin is stored in secretory vesicles in [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) and is released on glucose stimulation by exocytosis as shown in Figure 1. Mitochondrial functions are essential for this glucose stimulated insulin secretion. Mitochondrial dysfunction and [mutations](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/mutations-9811.html) in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) insulin secretion and T2DM [ [67](#67), [68](#68)]. mtDNA consists of two regions, coding region which codes for RNAs and control region which controls the expression of the mtDNA [ [69](#69)]. Variants arise due to [mutations](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/mutations-9811.html) in any of these regions in the DNA during [evolution](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/evolution-18620.html) [ [70](#70)]. Also, the weak repair mechanism in mitochondria is inefficient as compared to the nuclear DNA repair mechanism and hence allows transmission of these [mutations](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/mutations-9811.html) at a higher rate [ [69](#69), [71](#71)]. mtDNA is inherited only from the mother and thus the mutation occurred in mtDNA can only be transmitted via mother to child. Approximately 1% of all [diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) patients are suffering from maternally inherited [diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) and deafness (MIDD) which is a rare form of diabetes caused due to specific mtDNA mutation. This mutation was first discovered by Van den et al. [ [72](#72)] in 1992 in a Dutch family and by Reardon et al. [ [73](#73)] in a UK family. MIDD is mainly caused due to A to G substitution at the conserved position 3243 (m.3243A>G) of the mtDNA and so far, it is investigated by several investigators [ [74](#74)- [76](#76)]. Maternal mitochondria are inherited by the offspring and thus the prevalence of T2DM could be attributed to maternal inheritance [ [77](#77)]. Recently Crispim et al. [ [78](#78)] has investigated the prevalence of ten described mtDNA mutations in MIDD patients from Brazil. They have also studied most common A3243G mutation in the tRNA Leu (UUR) [gene](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/gene-4901.html) in these patients along gene, the 16S-rRNA [gene](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/gene-4901.html) and ATPase8 gene. Thus, they have stated the importance of mtDNA [mutations](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/mutations-9811.html) in the [pathogenesis](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/pathogenesis-19450.html) of MIDD and other T2DM patients. A common mitochondrial variant called 16189 variant is a result of T to C substitution at nucleotide position 16189 in the hypervariable D-loop (control) region of mtDNA [ [80](#80), [70](#70)]. Ye et al. [ [81](#81)] has reported in their review on Europid [population study](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/population-study-10022.html) that Ori B variant i.e. 16181-16193 polycytosine variant, of mtDNA augments the probability of prevalence of T2DM. Tawata et al. [ [76](#76)] has mentioned about another mutation in mtDNA at 14577 T/C which may probably be an important cause of maternally inherited T2DM. Liu et al. [ [82](#82)] has found novel mtDNA [mutations](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/mutations-9811.html) in MIDD in Chinese population. Similarly Tang et al. [ [83](#83)] has shown variation in mtDNA [mutations](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/mutations-9811.html) associated with T2DM in a Chinese population. Due to these inherited and acquired defects, [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) and T2DM patients show impaired mitochondrial function in their skeletal muscles [ [84](#84), [85](#85)]. This results in accumulation of FFAs, which causes reduction in insulin stimulated muscle glucose transport. This leads to fall in muscle glycogen synthesis and glycolysis [ [35](#35), [86](#86)]. Defective insulin stimulated glucose transport is an early event in the [pathogenesis](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/pathogenesis-19450.html) of T2DM [ [87](#87)]. Molecular Markers in T2DM Occurrence of T2DM is associated with alteration in expression of a number of genes. Detection of these alterations in the [gene](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/gene-4901.html) expression is useful in revealing the stage of disease in the patients and provides a better understanding for its treatment. Endothelial dysfunction related molecular markers in T2DM One of the major complications caused due to T2DM is the development of cardiovascular disease in human. The endothelium plays a very important role in the regulation of production of vasodilator [molecules](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/molecules-6279.html) such as Nitric Oxide (NO), prostacyclin, factor (EDHF), and vasoconstrictors such as Endothelin-1 (ET- 1) and angiotensin II for maintenance of arterial quality and proper blood flow [ [88](#88)]. Endothelial dysfunction is related to insulin resistance, inflammation, atherosclerosis and [cardiovascular](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cardiovascular-14501.html) disease in T2DM [ [89](#89)- [91](#91)]. Thus, the expression of molecular markers released by [endothelial cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/endothelial-cells-11652.html) can provide us an estimate about endothelial dysfunction in these patients. Loss of bioavailability of NO, overproduction of vasoconstrictors and imbalanced regulation of inflammation, thrombosis, and [cell growth](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cell-growth-17221.html) in the vascular wall are the major signs of endothelial dysfunction [ [88](#88), [92](#92)]. Numerous studies have confirmed that the dysfunction of endothelium causes development of atherosclerosis and insulin resistance in obese and T2DM patients [ [93](#93)- [95](#95)]. In normal condition, proper regulation of NO by endothelium prevents leukocyte adhesion and [inflammation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/inflammation-2448.html) of arterial wall endothelium enhances the [pathogenesis](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/pathogenesis-19450.html) of atherosclerotic vascular disease. This results into [inflammation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/inflammation-2448.html) and thrombosis of arterial wall which interfere in regulation of arterial tendency and flow [ [91](#91), [96](#96)]. In these conditions, the dysfunctional endothelium is to the endothelial surface [ [97](#97)- [90](#90)]. PAI-1 causes accumulation of extracellular matrix in kidneys thereby leading to diabetic [nephropathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/nephropathy-17261.html) [ [100](#100)]. Upregulation of PAI-1 and platelet by by vascular endothelium [ [101](#101)]. In T2DM patients, this activity becomes faulty due to lack of insulin. As a result, platelets adhere to vascular endothelium and aggregate more readily, contributing to faulty macrovascular and microvascular events [ [102](#102)]. Overall, it is clear that endothelial dysfunction is very well linked to [cardiovascular](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cardiovascular-14501.html) problems in T2DM patients. Cytokines and chemokines markers in Cytokines molecular weight polypeptides having autocrine, paracrine, and juxtacrine activity. They are classified into several different types such as interleukins, [tumor](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/tumor-109.html) necrosis factors, interferons, colony-stimulating factors, transforming growth factors and chemokines. Cytokines are produced by a wide variety of [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) in the body and also have great therapeutic potential [ [103](#103)]. Cytokines are involved in [pathogenesis](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/pathogenesis-19450.html) of DM and its complications. Inflammatory cytokines like IL-1, IL-6, IL-18 and TNF- play major role in development and progression of diabetic [nephropathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/nephropathy-17261.html) [107]. Inflammatory proteins are other important molecular markers of T2DM. Elevated levels of IL-6, TNF-, TGF- and CRP are stated to be involved in development of T2DM [ [58](#58), [104](#104), [105](#105)]. High production of IL- 1 is induced in [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) due to hyperglycemia, resulting in faulty insulin secretion, deficient cell proliferation, and [apoptosis](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/apoptosis-5333.html) [ [59](#59)]. Moriwaki et al. [ [106](#106)] has discussed elevated levels of IL- 18 along with that of IL-6 and TNF- in the serums of T2DM patients. On the other hand, it is observed that the serum concentration of anti-inflammatory proteins like adiponectin and IL-10 is reduced in obese and diabetic patients [ [107](#107), [108](#108)]. Irisin and other [molecules](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/molecules-6279.html) as markers for [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) and T2DM A recent discovery has introduced Irisin as a molecular marker in obesity, metabolic syndrome and T2DM. Irisin level is lower in T2DM patient serum compared to that in non-diabetic person [ [109](#109)]. Irisin is an exercise-mediated myokine, which controls energy metabolism by inducing browning of white [adipose tissue](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/adipose-tissue-8301.html) and thus converts chemical energy to heat energy. Bostrom et al. [ [110](#110)] has reported amelioration of glucose levels and [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) induced by Irisin in humans and mice. Exercise induced mild increase in Irisin levels was shown to boost energy expenditure in mice. Thus, Irisin controls diet induced weight gain and its effects like obesity, [insulin resistance](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/insulin-resistance-14070.html) and T2DM. The studies on caveolin-1 (CAV-1) [gene](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/gene-4901.html) expression in obese and diabetic patients by Catalan et al. [ [111](#111)] show that there is an upregulation of CAV-1 in the patients. CAV-1 is known to play important roles in many facets of cellular biology, such as vesicular transport, cholesterol homeostasis and signal transduction. This study implies that CAV-1 probably has some function in prevalence of [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) and [obesity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/obesity-4395.html) associated T2DM. Lancha et al. [ STX8 is an important protein in endosome transport mechanism. The study suggests that high expression of STX8 may possibly be associated with glucose transport mechanism and occurrence of T2DM in obese patients. Visfatin or pre-B cell (PBEF) apelin are adipocyte secreted [hormones](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/hormones-6945.html) highly expressed in visceral fat and blood of obese patients. Visfatin promotes the growth of B cell precursors and acts as an insulin analog on the insulin receptor. Studies have reported that visfatin and apelin levels could be associated with occurrence of T2DM [ [113](#113), [114](#114)]. Some studies have investigated the role of mutation in Calpain-10 [gene](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/gene-4901.html) in development of T2DM. Calpain- 10 is a expressed member of the calpain-like cysteine protease family. Calpain-10 is thought to be involved in [glucose metabolism](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/glucose-metabolism-8331.html) [ [115](#115), [116](#116)]. Further study of the function of these genes and their products is required to obtain a better understanding of their roles in glucose homeostasis. Mutations in certain other genes crucial for development and functioning of pancreas and liver have been shown to be responsible for development of T2DM. NEUROD1, receptor substrate-1 (IRS- 1), Insulin receptor (INSR) and High Mobility Group A1 (HMGA1) are such essential genes associated with progression of T2DM [ [117](#117), [118](#118)]. However, further investigation is necessary to conclude the susceptibility of these genes in development of T2DM in human. Complications Associated with T2DM The complications associated with T2DM intensify the state of [morbidity](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/morbidity-12546.html) and mortality of the patients. [Diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) complications are of two types- microvascular, which are caused due to damage to small blood vessels and macrovascular, which are caused due to damage to larger blood vessels. Microvascular complications include retinopathy leading to blindness, nephropathy leading to renal failure and [neuropathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/neuropathy-13020.html) leading to impotence and diabetic foot disorders including severe infections, which may even lead to amputation. Macrovascular complications include [cardiovascular](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cardiovascular-14501.html) diseases like heart attacks, strokes and deficiency of blood flow to legs [ [119](#119)]. We have further discussed some of these complications and their association with incidence of T2DM. Retinopathy Diabetic retinopathy is a very common microvascular complication associated with diabetes, leading to blindness in a large number of people suffering from [diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) per year [ [120](#120)]. It is a chronic ocular disorder developing, to some extent, in almost all diabetic patients as the disease progresses. The common characteristics of [diabetic retinopathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetic-retinopathy-4835.html) are retinal non perfusion, wherein the blood supply to the [retina](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/retina-8729.html) ceases because of alterations in microvasculature causing lesions in retina. In addition, increase in vasopermeability, capillary degeneration, uncontrolled neovascularization and macular edema is also observed [ [121](#121)]. Maintenance of euglycemia and control on blood pressure helps in delaying [diabetic retinopathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetic-retinopathy-4835.html) and slowing its progress. Procedures used for treating diabetic retinopathy are cryotherapy, virectomy and laser photocoagulation. The recent treatment procedures include injection of [steroid](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/steroid-6959.html) triamcinolone and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) antagonists into the eye [ [121](#121), [122](#122)]. Nephropathy Nephropathy develops in 30-40% of diabetes patients and the main causal factor is hyperglycemia. Other factors responsible are hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and proteinuria. Diabetic [nephropathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/nephropathy-17261.html) is characterized by persistent microalbuminuria, hyperfiltration and renal lesions in patients. In the earlier stages of the disease, accumulation of extracellular matrix in the mesangium and glomerular basement membrane is observed. As the disease progresses, mesangial nodules are formed and tubulointerstitial lesions are seen [ [123](#123), [124](#124)]. The symptoms of the disease in earlier stages can be reversed by insulin treatment [ [123](#123)]. The best treatment approach for diabetic [nephropathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/nephropathy-17261.html) is pancreas [transplantation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/transplantation-3766.html) [ [124](#124), losartan and angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are used for therapy. However, patients suffer from the side effects of these [drugs](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/drugs-2383.html) [ [126](#126), [127](#127)]. Neuropathy The peripheral nerve dysfunction observed in diabetic patients is called diabetic neuropathy [ [128](#128)]. It affects different parts of the nervous system. The most common diabetic neuropathies are Diabetic Peripheral [Neuropathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/neuropathy-13020.html) (DPN) and Diabetic Autonomic [Neuropathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/neuropathy-13020.html) (DAN). DPN patients suffer from loss of reflexes and sensations, especially in their lower limbs. They experience burning, pricking, electrical, stabbing or tingling sensations. Some patients experience extreme numbness. Almost half of the DPN cases are asymptomatic. These patients are at risk of developing ulcers, which may even lead to amputations. DAN may affect any of these organs- heart, lungs, blood vessels, bone, adipose tissue, sweat glands, gastrointestinal system and genitourinary system. The patients suffer from gastroparesis, constipation, diarrhea, anhidrosis, bladder dysfunction, erectile dysfunction, resting tachycardia, silent ischemia, and sudden cardiac death [ [129](#129), [130](#130)]. Like earlier discussed complications, diabetic neuropathies also develop as [diabetes](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/diabetes-866.html) progresses. The accurate pathophysiology of diabetic neuropathies is unknown but is probably related to polyol accumulation, generation of Advanced Glycation End (AGEs) products and Reactive Oxygen [Species](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/species-10593.html) (ROS) [ [131](#131)]. There is no cure to reverse diabetic neuropathy till date but the symptoms of the disease can be treated [ [129](#129), [131](#131)]. Therapeutic [drugs](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/drugs-2383.html) are prescribed to the patient depending upon the symptoms shown by the patient and the type of [neuropathy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/neuropathy-13020.html) implicated. Anticonvulsants [ [129](#129), [132](#132), [133](#133)]. Other anticonvulsants and amitriptyline block hence have analgesic effect [ [133](#133), [135](#135)]. [Acupuncture](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/acupuncture-8520.html) and electrical stimulation are other effective treatment procedures [ [133](#133)]. There is no single efficient treatment for diabetic neuropathy; various procedures discussed are utilized in synergy to give the patient a successful treatment. Although the treatment procedures used to treat these disorders are effective, they have certain side effects. In addition, these procedures do not cure the diseases but only heal the symptoms. The best cure for these complications associated with DM is lowering the blood sugar level and blood pressure. Maintenance of euglycemia and normal blood pressure helps in delaying these complications and slowing their progress. Therapies of T2DM Oral therapeutic agents The main goal of therapy of DM is to maintain euglycemia. Maintenance of normal blood glucose levels reduces risks of related metabolic syndromes. Physicians prescribe a particular drug keeping in mind several aspects and their adverse effects. Various oral antihyperglycemic agents are equally efficient in lowering blood glucose concentrations and HbA1c, except for the Alpha glucosidase inhibitors (AGIs) and nateglinide. Sulfonylureas result in reduction of microvascular complications, while metformin result in reduction of microvascular as well as macrovascular risks. Insulin sensitizers, [metformin](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/metformin-3870.html) and TZDs, avoid the possibility of [hypoglycemia](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/hypoglycemia-8297.html) associated with secretagogue therapy [ [4](#4)]. Majority of patients suffering from T2DM require multiple therapy to attain normal glycemic levels, as monotherapy rarely serves the purpose and if it does, it takes comparatively very long time [ [4](#4), [136](#136)]. These therapeutic agents provide a control over hyperglycemia; however they are not efficient in curing the disease and related complications permanently. In addition, they cause several side effects. Recent developments in [stem cell therapy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cell-therapy-6987.html) would provide a better solution over these problems. In fact, the disease can be permanently sorted out by this approach. Also, unlike organ transplantations, [stem cell therapy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cell-therapy-6987.html) does not face problems like graft rejection and shortage of donors. The patients' own [stem cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cells-15159.html) can be differentiated in vitro to islet [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) and these autologous [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) can serve the purpose for curing this disease [ [1](#1), [6](#6)]. Stem [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) therapy a new avenue for treatment of T2DM Stem [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) have enormous potential to divide and differentiate into various different types of specialized [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) of the body. Thus, [stem cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cells-15159.html) therapy is a promising key not only for treatment of T2DM but also for many other disorders and diseases for which complete cure is not yet available. Stem [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) could prove to be a non-exhausting source of the degenerated [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) in T2DM patients [ [6](#6)]. Figure 2 illustrates major causes of T2DM in human. There are two major faults associated, one is impairment of insulin function and other is cell dysfunction [ [137](#137), [138](#138)]. Both the aspects of -cell [physiology](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/physiology-5403.html) can be comprehensively corrected with stem cell therapy. [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) can be cultivated from stem cells and used further for transplantations in diabetic patients. Research is going on for developing and establishing functional cell mass from different types of stem cells. Recent progress in research raises hopes for T2DM patients to be cured in future by this miraculous therapy. Human embryonic stem cells: Human Embryonic [Stem Cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cells-15159.html) (HESCs) are the cells derived from the early human embryo and can propagate indefinitely in the undifferentiated state while exhibiting pluripotency. They are capable of giving rise to [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) derived from all three germ layers. Thus, these [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) can be cultured in vitro and further differentiated to provide a source of various specialized cells that can be used for replacement therapies of degenerative diseases [ [139](#139)]. Barclay et al. [ [140](#140)] has described a study where ESCs were successfully used in concert with oral therapeutic [drugs](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/drugs-2383.html) like [metformin](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/metformin-3870.html) or sitagliptin to treat T2DM in mice. et al. [ [141](#141)] derived pancreatic from in vivo. D'Amour et [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) were differentiated by process designed to imitate the in vivo development process of the islet cells. The study of Cai et al. [ [143](#143)] has revealed that NGN3 expressing [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) and A and also differentiate in vivo to insulin, glucagon, and somatostatin producing cells. The [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) thus obtained from hESCs express cell markers and exhibit their functions too [ [141](#141), [144](#144)]. ESCs are less immunologically potent than allogenic adult [stem cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cells-15159.html) and hence may require less immune suppression [ [6](#6)]. However, ESCs stand the risk of developing into teratomas from the undifferentiated fraction of the transplanted cells. The other limitation of the use of ESCs is the ethical issues involved and therefore use of hESCs is restricted in [stem cell](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cell-770.html) therapy. Mesenchymal stem cells: Mesenchymal Stem [Cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) (MSCs) can be obtained from various body tissues, viz. bone marrow, adipose tissue ,umbilical cord or its blood , fibroblasts , endometrium, and liver cells; bone marrow being the richest source [ [138](#138), [145](#145), [146](#146)]. Bone marrow derived MSCs are highly capable of self-replicating and differentiating, both in vitro and in vivo, to various tissue cells. They are easy to cultivate and remain pluripotent for long durations of culturing. They maintain the capacity of multilineage differentiation [ [6](#6)]. Jiang et al. [ [145](#145)] has reported that the multipotent adult progenitor mesenchymal [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) proliferate extensively without any apparent senescence or loss of differentiation potential, and hence they may be an ideal cell source for therapy of inherited or degenerative diseases such as diabetes. Bone marrow derived MSCs [transplantation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/transplantation-3766.html) in concert with hyperbaric oxygen treatment is found to be effective in improvising metabolic variables such as fasting plasma glucose, C-peptide, HbA1c and C-peptide/glucose ratio, as well as reduction in insulin requirements [ [147](#147)]. Bone marrow MSCs can be effectively used to produce glucose induced insulin-secreting cells, arrest insulin resistance, recovery of liver and pancreas damage and to cure diabetic ulcers and limb ischemia. MSCs transplantation also results in elevation of GLUT4, insulin receptor substrate 1 (IRS-1) and Akt (protein kinase B) [ [148](#148)- [150](#150)]. MSCs were shown to suppress diabetogenic T [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) and thus prevented autoimmune cell destruction and other related disorders in mice [ [151](#151)]. Zhao et al. [ [152](#152)] worked on Bone marrow MSCs to study their effect on pathogenic action of hyperglycaemia in T2DM. Their findings reveal that there was an improvement of cell function and survival induced by MSCs mediated through autophagy; also the alterations caused due to hyperglycemia were reversed. An alternative source of stem cells, peripheral blood could provide a more non-invasive approach. The mesenchymal stem [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) thus obtained from the peripheral blood can be used in future regenerative [stem cell](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cell-770.html) therapy [ [32](#32)]. The effects of single MSCs transplantation are relatively short. In order to obtain long term maintenance of euglycemia, multiple intravenous transplantations must be carried out. Multiple infusions effectively maintain normal glucose levels and ameliorate the pathogenic effects of [hyperglycaemia](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/hyperglycaemia-19524.html) [ [153](#153), [154](#154)]. MSCs are the most studied type of [stem cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cells-15159.html) for DM therapy. However, the safety and efficacy of MSCs therapy needs to be confirmed yet so as to use this approach for treatment. Induced pluripotent stem cells: Induced Pluripotent [Stem Cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cells-15159.html) (IPSCs) are developed from differentiated adult somatic [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) by establishing expression of early development genes Oct3/4 and Sox2, along with cMyc embryonic-like [stem cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cells-15159.html) show high clonogenicity and are able to give rise to cell lineages from all three germ layers. This technology can hence be exploited to produce fully functional [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) [ [155](#155)- [157](#157)]. Jeon et al. [ [158](#158)] illustrated that IPSCs cultured from non-obese diabetic mice show typical ESCs-like characteristics such as expression of markers for pluripotency, in vitro differentiation, teratoma formation, and generation of chimeric mice. It was also demonstrated that epithelial [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) derived from the pancreas of the nonobese diabetic mice differentiated more readily into insulin-producing [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) and expressed various pancreatic cell markers. These cells also secreted insulin in response to glucose and KCl stimulation. [Transplantation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/transplantation-3766.html) of these cells into diabetic mice led to kidney engraftment. The engrafted [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) successfully normalized blood glucose levels by insulin secretion. Thus, patient-derived IPSCs can prove to be a potential therapy for autologous cell [transplantation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/transplantation-3766.html) for treating diabetes. Alipio et al. [ [159](#159)] successfully achieved long term amelioration of hyperglycemia in mice by transplanting iPSC derived pancreatic -like cells. The [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) obtained efficiently secreted insulin in response to glucose stimulation and lowered blood glucose and hemoglobin A1C levels. T2DM is a cosmopolitan disease and yet incurable in spite of long periods of research and efforts. Tissue regeneration and [stem cell therapy](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cell-therapy-6987.html) is a ray of hope for the treatment for this wide spreading disease. However, the safety issues involved must be considered and further advancements in the protocols are required before clinical application of this study so as to provide patients an effective long term treatment. The efficacy and mechanism of [stem cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cells-15159.html) also needs to be determined so as to understand study well and make new researches to develop better treatment. Conclusion T2DM being an ancient disease, cure of this disease has not been possible due to lack of study of the various mechanisms causing this disease. Due to advancements in Molecular Medicine and [Stem Cell](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/stem-cell-770.html) Research, there are hopes for the use of these advance technologies for complete cure of T2DM. This review has mainly highlighted the important mechanisms involved in occurrence of T2DM, Molecular profiling, Insulin resistance, endothelial dysfunction and related Molecular Markers. There is a probability of developing stem cell therapies by using MSCs or IPSCs [cells](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/cells-5868.html) for autologous [transplantation](https://www.openaccessjournals.com/peer-reviewed-articles/transplantation-3766.html) for complete cure of this disease. This review will be of importance for future studies to be carried out in this area by researchers, clinicians, endocrinologists and diabetologists to define T2DM precisely and discover some key for the treatment of T2DM in humans.
